ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Camp Frio Facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  Camp Frio Facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Camp Frio Facility is located as 31912 Merced Avenue, Bakersfield, California. 93308.  The regulated substance managed at the facility is anhydrous ammonia.  The maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 16,000 pounds (lbs.).  The system is used for refrigeration for the production process.  





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Camp Frio Facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facility is limited to a maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia of 16,000 lbs.  Therefore, the regulated substance is over the 10,000-lb. threshold for the US EPA RMP and the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal/OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) threshold quantities and over the 500-lb. state threshold for CalARP Program.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program 3.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: One worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the Ammonia Refrigeration System.  



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: An alternative release scenario was modeled. 



Risk Considerati

ons

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Camp Frio Facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such event.



In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:

?Well-designed Relief System and Relief Valves are tied to Diffusion Tank

?Gas Detection Systems and Alarms

?Safety Showers/Eyewash Stations



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR ?2750.9, the owner or operator shall submit the data required under ?2745.5, and ?2745.7 with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under ?2745.10, whichever is earlier.  19 CCR ?2750.9 states:

The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Camp Frio Facility has had no releases in the last five years that meets the five-year accident history reporting criteria, therefore no data is required. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Camp Frio Facility is a non-responding facility and does not train employees for active responses to ammonia releases.  This facility

will relay upon the local emergency hazardous materials response team and the local Fire Department for responses to uncontrolled releases of anhydrous ammonia.  In accordance with 19 CCR ?2765.1, the facility is not required to have an Emergency Response Plan in place.  It is required to have appropriate mechanisms in place for notifying emergency responders when there is a need for response.  These mechanisms are described below.  



The Facility has submitted a Hazardous Material Inventory (HMI) Business Plan via California Environmental Reporting System (CERS), which was reviewed and approved by the Kern County Environmental Health, Bilal Korin, on May 1, 2019.



The Facility has procedures in place to evacuate the facility and notify responders when there is a need for a response.  A current copy of the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) can be found with the Plant Manager and it includes;

?Emergency Alarm Procedures

?Evacuation Procedures

?Safety and Health Considerations

?Notification Procedures



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  These studies include the following: Process Hazard Analysis (PHA and Hazard Assessment, performed on August 20, 2020.  Any outstanding recommendations from these studies will have been addressed by February 20, 2023.



EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT

Pursuant to the requirements of California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section ?2745.7(l), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of anhydrous ammonia were addressed by the August 20, 2020 PHA for the ammonia refrigeration system covered process.  Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions.



Description of the types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA 19 CCR ?2760.2 or Hazard Review 19 CCR ?2755.2.  

During the PHA, a broad list of external events was cons

idered by the PHA Team.  However, the Team only deemed some of these events as being credible, and fully developed those scenarios that present an opportunity for ammonia release.  



The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered.  If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.



The magnitude of the external events considered is detailed within the August 20, 2020 PHA Worksheets.



For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply  

- The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;

- Major hazards identified;

- Process controls in use;

- Mitigation systems in use;

- Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,

- Changes since the last PHA.



Refer to Section 7.4 section of the RMPe*submit, under PHA, for the required information.



The recommendations precipitating from the August 20, 2020 PHA are summarized in the "PHA" report.  All recommendations are documented, with a date of a completion and description of the action required.



The Human Factors were discussed in the August 20, 2020 PHA, as a separate node.  The worksheets can be found in the PHA report, which also include; major hazards identified, process controls in use, mitigation systems in use, and monitoring and detection systems in use.



There were no significant changes since the last PHA.  The date of the most recent field verification that equipment is installed and maintained as designed is April 15, 2015 and included:  refrigeration system pressures and temperatures, inspection of all valve stations for leaks and the normal inspection of the entire system equipment.
